article.description: For the third straight game,  Missouri fell behind and then rallied only to fall short, losing 71-67 Tuesday night to Belmont of the Atlantic Sun Conference.
article.headline: Bruins shot more 3s than 2s, 35-20
article.story: COLUMBIA, Mo. (AP) -- Missouri coach Quin Snyder had no complaints about the boos for the home team from the Hearnes Center crowd on Tuesday night. "It's not disappointing to me," Snyder said after Missouri (No. 22 ESPN/USA Today, No. 23 AP) lost 71-67 to Belmont. "How we played is disappointing. I feel like we should boo ourselves." After reaching as high as No. 3 this season, Missouri has lost three in a row and four of five. Snyder is 88-53 overall in four seasons at Missouri, but just 13-12 in December. Steve Drabyn had 16 points for Belmont (6-3) of the Atlantic Sun Conference, while Nick Otis added 15, Adam Mark 14 and Jese Snyder 12. The Bruins shot more 3s than 2s, 35-20, and made 13 shots from beyond the arc. "We've got a lot of shooters," Belmont coach Rick Byrd said. "The truth of the matter is, our shooters made shots better than theirs did tonight." Missouri was 24-for-57 (42 percent) from the field, and just 7-for-26 (27 percent) from 3-point range. Freshman Linas Kleiza scored 10 straight first-half points and 18 overall for Missouri, while Rickey Paulding had 21, Jimmy McKinney 15 and Arthur Johnson 10. The rest of the Tigers combined for three points. For the third straight game, Missouri fell behind by double figures, only to rally before falling just short. Missouri appeared headed for an easy win after taking a 31-21 lead late in the first half. But a 36-14 run put Belmont up 57-47 with 8:50 to play. Missouri went on a 12-2 run to tie it at 59 on Jason Conley's free throw with 3:29 to play, before Belmont went back ahead for good. The Tigers had a chance with 12 seconds left when Drabyn missed the front end of a 1-and-1. But Belmont's Adam Mark scrambled for the rebound and Drabyn, fouled again, made both free throws with 8 seconds left. Otis said the undersized Bruins used a set play to get the game-saving rebound. "We have a play where our two guys try to cross -- almost like a screen," Otis said. "It worked to perfection." Missouri outrebounded Belmont 41-30, but had trouble working the ball inside against the Bruins' 2-3 zone. The Tigers also turned the ball over 15 times, often leading to Belmont 3-pointers the other way. Kleiza, a 6-foot-8 native of Lithuania, scored on a layup with 14:40 to play in the half, then connected on two layups, a dunk and two free throws to help Missouri go on top in the first half, when the Tigers were seemingly in control of the game. Then Belmont's 3s began to fall, leading to a 17-3 spurt that put the Bruins ahead 38-34 with 18 minutes to play. Missouri fell 12 places in the AP poll last week after a one-point loss to Illinois on Dec. 23 and a two-point loss at Memphis on Dec. 27. Missouri has made a habit of falling behind and then rallying. Early this season, the rallies led to wins, such as when the Tigers overcame a 14-point deficit in the final seven minutes to beat Indiana. Not lately. Missouri was down by 21 points to Illinois before tying the game with just over a minute to play, only to lose 71-70. The Tigers trailed Memphis by 15 before rallying, only to lose by two when McKinney's last-second 3-pointer clanged off the rim. "We need to compete for 40 minutes," Snyder said. "We're not playing with urgency right now. We have guys who have been through this before who should know what it takes to play at this level. That's not happening right now."
